head.title: Ferroelectric and Charge Transport Properties in Strain-Engineered Two-Dimensional Lead Iodide Perovskites | Chemistry of Materials

meta.content: Ferroelectric and Charge Transport Properties in Strain-Engineered Two-Dimensional Lead Iodide Perovskites

Transitions from three-dimensional (3D) hybrid organic–inorganic perovskite (HOIP) structures to lower dimensions including 2D and quasi-2D structures open a new range of functional properties in these materials systems. Yet, the performance of solar cells made from 2D HOIP is below that of the 3D compositions due to the higher band-gap energy, low carrier concentration, and anisotropy in charge transport. Controlling ferroelectricity in 2D HOIPs is considered to be a powerful strategy to drive the spatial separation of photogenerated charge carriers to improve the photovoltaic action in this class of HOIPs. Here, we explore the strain-dependent ferroelectricity and charge carrier properties in strain-engineered 2D-layered HOIPs utilizing advanced scanning probe microscopy (SPM) techniques. Band excitation-piezoresponse force microscopy (BE-PFM) and contact Kelvin probe force microscopy (cKPFM) reveal ferroelectric domains and switchable dynamics with significantly low switching voltages in the low-strain film. Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy shows strain-dependent optical properties and a noncentrosymmetric structure with strong second-harmonic generation (SHG) peaks in the low-strain film. In addition, KPFM results demonstrate a higher surface potential in the low-strain films, while the photovoltage and local current are the highest on the high-strain film. Our study demonstrates the critical role of strain engineering on the electromechanical and charge carrier dynamics in 2D HOIPs, which is important for development of 2D HOIP devices.

div.p: Transitions from three-dimensional (3D) hybrid organic–inorganic perovskite (HOIP) structures to lower dimensions including 2D and quasi-2D structures open a new range of functional properties in these materials systems. div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Hybrid organic–inorganic perovskites (HOIPs) have attracted much attention as the next-generation photovoltaic materials due to their superlative optoelectronic properties.
(1−3)
In particular, three-dimensional (3D) HOIPs have provided solar cells with power conversion efficiencies over 25.5%.
(4)
However, the key issue of environmental stability has hampered their widespread applications, and thus, an ongoing effort toward discovery of more stable perovskites is in progress. Two-dimensional (2D) HOIPs
(5−8)
with impressive structural and compositional diversity and excellent optoelectronic properties have been evolved as an important class of more stable perovskites owing to effectively reduced trap densities
(9)
and long-chain hydrophobic cations.
(10,11)
However, so far their photovoltaic performance lags behind 3D perovskites due to a lower carrier concentration,
(12)
anisotropic charge carrier transport,
(13)
and a higher exciton binding energy,
(14)
necessitating further understanding of carrier dynamics and pathways to tune the functional responses in these materials.

One of the incipient functionalities of HOIPs is the presence of ferroelectricity emerging due to structural instabilities associated with polar zone center phonon modes. It has been argued that the photovoltaic performance can be improved in ferroelectric semiconductors due to the effective spatial separation of photogenerated charge carriers.
(15,16)
This is because the internal field induced by spontaneous polarization (P
s
) aids the spatial separation of charge carriers, and thus, the presence of ferroelectricity at room temperature is expected to enhance the photovoltaic performance. The improved photovoltaic effect has been observed in ferroelectric domain walls in classical perovskites.
(17−19)
This ferroelectricity can be modulated by strain engineering.
(20−22)
While the presence of ferroelectricity in 3D polycrystalline HOIPs remains controversial,
(23−25)
recently, ferroelectricity in 2D HOIPs has been demonstrated in various compositions,
(26−31)
which originates from a large freedom of organic cation motions in these materials. For example, the saturation polarization or maximum polarization in a P–E loop,
P
max
, was found to be around 9.8 μC/cm
2
in 4-(aminomethyl) piperidinium lead iodide,
(26)
which is relatively higher than other bromide-
(27,29)
and chloride-
(32)
based 2D HOIPs.

Recently, a ferroelectric large polaron has been proposed to explain the electronic properties of HOIPs.
(33)
The electrons are localized at the domain boundaries where the local field from the charge carriers leads to a ferroelectric large polaron.
(33)
In this model, Coulomb screening resulting from polaron formation in solvated states reduces the charge carrier scattering from charged defects, and the phonons.
(33,34)
The high level of disorder from the localized charge carriers leads to relaxor ferroelectrics where polar nanoregions are formed, similar to nanoscale domains. In HOIPs, relaxor dynamics derive from the phase separation of either the anion or the cation lattice and the spin-polarized properties of organic cations.
(24)
In particular, 2D HOIPs naturally form multiple quantum wells (
n
) between the inorganic perovskite layers which act as barriers for the organic layers, and hence, 2D HOIPs structurally have significant ferroelectricity with large polarons.
(34)
Thus, it is expected that their optical and electronic properties can be modulated by the thickness of the quantum wells or organic layers. Most recently, vortex–antivortex domain structures
(31)
have been shown in 2D 4,4-difluoropiperidinium (DFPD) lead iodide ((4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
) perovskites, making this composition an interesting model system in our studies.

Here, (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
crystals were successfully grown by a slow cooling crystallization process,
(31)
and then the as-grown crystals were used as a starting material for thin film deposition. We demonstrate crystallization- and strain-dependent thin films with different thickness prepared by drop-casting, spin-coating, and vacuum-poling treatment. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to compare the crystallinity of the thin films fabricated with different processing. Peak broadening analysis in the XRD patterns was used to calculate the strain disorder of the films. The effect of crystallization and strain disorder on the film surfaces was studied. Further, we explored the electromechanical responses using band excitation-piezoresponse force microscopy (BE-PFM). Simultaneously, contact Kelvin probe force microscopy (cKPFM) was employed to study the ferroelectricity in the films. The photoluminescence (PL) measurements were performed to investigate the optical properties. In addition, KPFM measurements were carried out in the dark and under illumination to measure the surface potentials and photovoltages. Finally, local
I–V
characteristics were explored using conductive atomic force microscopy (c-AFM) in the strain-engineered thin films. Our results provide an insightful understanding of the ferroelectric and charge carrier properties in strain-engineered (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin films.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
(4,4-difluoropiperidinium (DFPD))
2
PbI
4
single crystals were grown by slow cooling crystallization. 4,4-DFPD hydrochloride (0.1 M, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in the hydroiodic acid (HI) solution (10 mL, 57 wt % in H
2
O, Sigma-Aldrich) and then stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then PbI
2
(0.05 M, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to the solution. An orange powder precipitates from the undissolved PbI
2
, which was dissolved by heating the solution to 405 K in an oil bath. The solution was kept at the same temperature for 1 h, forming a clear solution. Slowly cooling the solution to room temperature for 4 days produced the needle-shaped crystals of (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
.

The as-grown (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
crystals (60 mg) were dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 200 μL) to prepare the precursor solution. The ITO (indium tin oxide)-coated glass substrates (MSE Pro, 15 × 15 × 1 mm
3
) were precleaned using deionized water, acetone, and isopropanol in an ultrasonic bath for 15 min. After the initial cleaning, the glass substrates were treated under UV ozone for 15 min. Then the substrates were transferred into a N
2
-filled glovebox for thin film deposition. For the drop casting sample, a precleaned ITO glass was placed on a hot plate at 373 K, and then about 5 μL of the precursor solution was carefully dropped on the hot substrate and dried for 10 min for full crystallization. For the spin-coated samples, about 20 μL of the solution was dispersed onto the substrate and then spin coated at 2000 rpm for 30 s. The spin-coated films were annealed at 373 K for 10 min. For the vacuum-treated films, the spin-coated films were transferred to the vacuum chamber for 7 min and then annealed at 373 K for 10 min.

The crystal structure and crystal orientation of the films were characterized by a high-resolution X-ray diffractometer (X’Pert Pro, PANalytical). The X-ray diffractometer used Cu Kα radiation. The Williamson–Hall plot was analyzed by calculating the full width at half-maximum of the XRD peaks using PANalytical X’Pert Pro software.

div.h3: Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM) Measurements: AFM, PFM, KPFM, and c-AFM
div.div:
The thin films were characterized by atomic force microscopy (AFM, MFP-3D, Asylum Research) under ambient conditions at room temperature. All SPM measurements were performed using a Pt/Ir-coated Si cantilever (ElectriMulti 75-G, Budget Sensors). For piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM), an ac drive amplitude (5 V) was applied to the PFM tip to achieve a sharp contact resonance peak. All PFM data were obtained with out-of-plane amplitude and phase in the same scan. For Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM), a lift height of 50 nm was used to detect the optimized contact potential difference. For conductive-AFM (c-AFM, ORCA), a dual-gain ORCA (Asylum Research) cantilever holder having a current range from 1 pA to 10 μA was used to measure the local
I–V
characteristics. A wire was mounted on the back of the holder and attached to the ITO substrate to build a closed circuit between the tip and the sample. For illumination, tunable white LED sources that were not filtered illuminated the sample from the bottom area through the glass substrate. In all SPM measurements, the scan rate was fixed at 1.0 Hz, and the scan direction started from top to bottom.

div.h4: Band Excitation-Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (BE-PFM) and Contact Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy (cKPFM) Measurements
div.div:
Band excitation (BE)-PFM and contact Kelvin probe force microscopy (cKPFM) were carried out using AFM (MFP-3D, Asylum Research) with an in-house controller (Look Instrument) and Labview-based software. The same AFM tip was used as above. BE mode uses a digitally synthesized ac voltage across a range of frequencies. A built-in lock-in amplifier was used to enhance the signal-to-noise in all BE-PFM and cKPFM measurements. The frequency range in the BE mode was centered at 380 kHz with a bandwidth of 100 kHz, and the drive amplitude for BE-PFM excitation was 5 V. The BE-PFM measurements were taken over a grid of 128 × 128 points on the sample surface. The voltage-dependent response is determined from a fit of the band excitation data to a simple harmonic oscillator (SHO) model. The signals such as amplitude, phase, resonance frequency, and quality (
Q
) factor are correctly obtained from the SHO model. The cKPFM measurements were taken over a grid of 10 × 10 points on the film surface. For the cKPFM measurements, a dc write voltage was applied stepwise as 0 V, +10 V, 0 V, −10 V, and back to zero consecutively with a total of 64 steps. These applied voltage steps are referred to as
V
write
. Between all
V
write
steps there is a read bias step (
V
read
), where the cKPFM responses are measured with a total of 11 steps between −10 and +10 V. The delay time between subsequent measurements is on the order of milliseconds. The piezoresponse measured at 0 V during the read measurements is shown in the off-field response. All measurements were carried out in the dark.

The steady-state PL measurements upon 1-photon and 2-photon excitation were measured using a Horiba Fluoro Log III spectrometer. The (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
crystals and thin films were excited using a continuous wave 405 nm semiconductor laser for 1-photon and a 1030 nm pulsed laser (200 kHz, 280 fs) for 2-photon photoluminescence measurements.

div.div:
A slow cooling crystallization method with hydroiodic acid (HI) was used to grow 4,4-difluoropiperidinium (DFPD) lead iodide ((4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
) 2D crystals. For fabrication of thin films, the as-grown crystals were dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to prepare the precursor solution. Although crystals were rinsed several times with dichloromethane (DCM), there were many irregular defects (
Figure S1
) on the surface of as-grown crystals, possibly due to residual HI solution or intrinsic surface defects formed during crystallization. This was removed by dissolving the crystals in DMSO. The prepared precursor solution was then deposited on the ITO glass substrates. Details of fabrication procedure can be found in the
Experimental Section
.
Figure
1
a shows a schematic illustration of the thin film fabrication with three different methods in this study.

div.p:
Figure 1. (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin film fabrication and characterization via XRD and AFM. (a) Schematics of (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
2D perovskite thin film deposition by drop casting, spin coating, and spin coating accompanied by vacuum poling treatment. (b) XRD patterns of fabricated thin films. (Inset) Williamson–Hall plots for the analysis of strain disorder in the films. The 3D AFM surface topography images of thin films deposited by (c) drop casting, (d) spin coating, and (e) spin coating with vacuum poling treatment.

div.div:
To investigate the crystallinity of the thin films with different fabrication conditions, XRD analysis was carried out. As shown in
Figure
1
b, the XRD peaks in all films correspond to the (0 2 0), (1 1 1), (0 6 0), (1 7 1), and (0 10 0) planes of a room-temperature orthorhombic structure with noncentrosymmetric
Aba
2 space group, consistent with a previous study.
(31)
However, the extent of crystallinity on individual planes is dependent on different fabrication conditions (see
Figure S2
). The strongest intensity among the XRD peaks is the (0 2 0) plane followed by (1 1 1) and (0 6 0) in the drop-casted sample. Similarly, relatively stronger intensities are observed from the (0 2 0) plane in both the spin-coated and the vacuum-treated samples, while the (0 6 0), and (1 7 1) planes have the next highest intensities. The different fabrication processes result in preferential growth along certain planes. These results are different from a previous study,
(31)
where the preferential plane is (1 7 1) followed by the (0 2 0) and (0 6 0) planes. We speculate that this difference can originate from crystal quality due to different growth conditions, especially the cooling rate. For example, a rapid cooling rate causes many nucleation sites in the solution, which leads to the formation of multiple small crystals. Importantly, strict control of the cooling rate can give rise to high-quality crystals.
(12)
It is interesting to note that the entire peak intensities are significantly increased for the spin-coated sample (red line,
Figure
1
b). These increased intensities suggest that the spin-coated sample has higher crystallinity than the drop-casted sample. However, the increased peak intensities decrease in the vacuum-treated sample accompanied by peak broadening. Recently, it was reported that vacuum treatment during fabrication of quasi-2D perovskites accelerates the nucleation process, results in uniformly dispersed film surfaces, and significantly decreases grain sizes to the nanoscale.
(35)
Similar to our study, the vacuum-treated sample shows smaller grain sizes as evidenced by the AFM image (
Figure
1
e), possibly due to an accelerated nucleation process during vacuum treatment. Further, in the XRD pattern of drop-casted sample, several small peaks are observed close to the main peaks that are indexed to the (0 6 0) and (1 7 1) planes of the 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
structure due to different crystallinity as mentioned above. We further analyzed the peak shape by studying the Williamson–Hall (W–H) plot to better understand the strain disorder in the three different samples. In the W–H analysis, isotropic strain broadening results in a straight line through the origin, (0 0), without a
y
-axis intercept,
(36)
while anisotropic strain results in a line which intercepts the
y
axis. In our result, we do not observe isotropic peak broadening in the planes. Instead, the result reveal anisotropic peak broadening. Thus, we analyze the highly oriented (0 1 0) lattice planes as shown in
Figure S3
. After the instrument function is removed, the full width at half-maximum (FWHM), β, is composed of the crystal size and strain components as given below
(1)
(2)
By multiplying by cos θ
(3)
where
is the intercept, 4ε is the slope, and β cos θ is plotted against sin θ.

Here, the XRD peak broadening calculated from the FWHM (β) is attributed to the high strain disorder in the film.
(37)
Generally, HOIPs experience anisotropic strain
(38,39)
having a higher strain along with a highly oriented plane.
(40)
In fact, the strain disorder is significantly different between highly oriented and minority planes in HOIPs.
(40)
This anisotropic strain in HOIPs is associated with an interplay between the cation rotations
(41)
and local distortion of the inorganic framework.
(42)
The analysis of strain disorder in the W–H plot is presented in the inset of
Figure
1
b. The strain disorders obtained from the slopes in the W–H plot are 0.05 (drop casted), 0.09 (spin coated), and 0.22 (spin/vacuum treated) (
Table S1
). The increase in strain disorder is significant in the vacuum-treated sample accompanying crystal size reduction due to accelerated nucleation in this method. The size of the crystallites is also determined from the FWHM through the Scherrer equation (130 nm for drop-cast film, 95 nm for spin-coated film, and 50 nm for spin- and vacuum-treated films).

Next, we explore the effect of crystallization and lattice strain on the morphology of (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
films using atomic force microscopy (AFM).
Figure
1
c–e compares the 3D surface topography of the fabricated films. The drop-casted and spin-coated samples exhibit nonuniform morphology, while the surface becomes much smoother with a regular morphology in the vacuum-treated sample (
Figure
1
e). The mean surface roughness for each sample is presented in
Table S2
. The roughness is considerably higher on the drop-casted sample and decreases significantly to ∼10 nm on the vacuum-treated sample. The film thickness is also measured with AFM scanning between the films and the ITO glass substrate as shown in
Figure S4
, revealing a thickness of around 2.5 μm for drop-casted, 250 nm for spin-coated, and 50 nm for spin/vacuum-treated samples. We note that the strain dependence in these samples may result from difference in the film thickness. Typically, when the film thickness increases, the increased elastic energy accompanying relatively larger defects, e.g., microscale cracks and holes, aids in relieving the strain, whereas when the film thickness is thinner, structural dislocation occurs resulting in defects, e.g., grain boundaries.
(43)
Recently, it has been experimentally demonstrated in the epitaxially grown HOIPs that there are no cracks and holes in the strained films, but as the film thickness increases, larger defects such as cracks and holes are generated, which leads to strain relaxation.
(44)
Macroscopically, we also observe more cracks on the thick films fabricated by drop casting as shown in
Figure S5
. Thus, the observed cracks on the film surface may contribute to the strain relaxation in this sample.

It is believed that the strain-induced lattice deformation can modulate the bond strength in the lattice, resulting in variation in the electronic band structure.
(45)
Typically, the lattice strain can be tuned by various parameters such as compositional difference,
(46)
film thickness,
(44)
and grain size.
(39)
For instance, the chemical inhomogeneity in polycrystalline 3D HOIPs induces intrinsic residual strain.
(47)
Thus, both external and internal strain in the lattice can have an impact on the optoelectronic properties. In addition, the residual strain contributes to the unfavorable carrier dynamics and phase stability.
(45)
Likewise, it is expected that the optoelectronic properties of 2D HOIPs can be tailored by strain engineering. This strain can be tuned via crystallinity, nucleation, and film thickness modification during thin film deposition.

To investigate the electromechanical response and ferroelectricity in the samples, single-frequency piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM),
(48−50)
band excitation (BE)-PFM,
(51−53)
and contact Kelvin probe force microscopy (cKPFM)
(54,55)
measurements were performed on the film surfaces. BE-PFM
(56)
and cKPFM
(54)
are multidimensional PFM spectroscopies developed for exploring ferroelectric domains and ferroelectricity. To rule out the effect of photogenerated charge carriers, all measurements were performed in the dark. Note that contact resonance frequency peaks are used for BE mode, and a simple harmonic oscillator (SHO) model is utilized to obtain the corrected images and cKPFM response curves.
(53,57)

Figure
2
a and
2
b shows single-frequency driven-PFM amplitude and phase images on the drop-casted films. The corresponding topography images are shown in
Figure S6
. We observed domain structures in some areas of these films corresponding to the topographical features. We also performed the PFM measurements on the spin-coated and spin/vacuum-treated samples to investigate the presence of ferroelectric domains in these films. The PFM images of spin-coated films are shown in
Figure S6
. Interestingly, vortex–antivortex-like domain structures are visible in some areas in the phase maps (
Figure S7c
), corresponding to the flower-like topographic features. However, no specific features can be observed in the nanosized grains of the vacuum-treated films (
Figure S8
). Overall, as the film deposition evolves from drop casting to spin coating and spin/vacuum treatment, the electromechanical responses, particularly the amplitude signals, become significantly weaker. In addition, the grain size variation induces structural strain which can modify the ferroelectric properties. In fact, the critical grain size suppresses the ferroelectricity in classical ferroelectric materials,
(58)
and such grain size is always correlated to the effect of grain boundaries. This effect will be further discussed later in the manuscript.

div.p:
Figure 2. PFM, BE-PFM and cKPFM measurements on the drop-casted (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin films in the dark. Single-frequency-driven (a) PFM amplitude and (b) phase images, (c) BE-PFM amplitude and (d) phase images, and cKPFM responses as a function of bias (e) on- and (f) off-field on the drop-casted sample. cKPFM responses in e and f are obtained from the locations denoted by “×” in the bottom right corner of c and d maps.

div.div:
To gain insight into the electromechanical responses and ferroelectric domain properties, we performed BE-PFM measurements on the three different samples. To minimize topological cross-talk, the measurements were carried out in smaller scanned areas of 5 × 5 μm
2
.
Figure
2
c and
2
d shows the BE-PFM amplitude and phase maps on the drop-casted films. The corresponding topography, resonance frequency, and quality factor maps are displayed in
Figure S9
. We observe ferroelectric domains with different polarization in the phase maps in this sample (
Figure
2
d). The domain patterns are visible in both PFM images. Such alternating domain patterns result from spontaneous polarization to compensate for the mechanical strain during phase transition.
Figures S10 and S11
show BE-PFM images on the spin-coated and spin/vacuum-treated films, revealing no polarized domain structures. In particular, no polarized domains are observed in the vortex-like features shown in the classical PFM. It is known that the ferroelectric domain features are highly dependent on strain, resulting from different crystallization and nucleation conditions. Interestingly, we notice strain-induced variations of the polarized domains in the films with different crystallization because strain can indeed control the vortex states.
(59)
However, details of the underlying mechanism will be explored in a future study.

Typically, PFM measurement offers only limited insight into the electromechanical properties of the film surfaces. In particular, when the materials surface is neither uniform nor smooth, the interaction between the tip and the topological variations can cause artifacts during scanning. Hence, we apply cKPFM
(54,55)
as an advanced technique to simultaneously measure the electromechanical responses and electrostatic phenomena. This will allow us to explore whether the material is real ferroelectric or exhibits ferroelectric-like behavior due to the surface electrochemistry
(60,61)
and ionic activity
(62−66)
or possibly exhibits mixed ferroionic states.
(67−69)
During cKPFM measurements, a gradually increasing and decreasing electrical bias waveform both on- and off-field is applied via a conductive tip to the sample as a function of two biases, denoted as
V
read
and
V
write
.
Figure
2
e and
2
f shows the cKPFM responses with on- and off-field responses between −10 and +10 V on the drop-casted film. The cKPFM responses as a function of
V
read
are nonlinear and hysteretic. Importantly, the hysteretic behavior with an on-field is maintained in an off-field. The switched dipole moments cause a remanent field at 0 V, which is indicative of ferroelectricity in this material. It is interesting to note that the switching voltage in our sample is significantly smaller, less than ±10 V as compared to around ±30 V in the previous report.
(31)
The ferroelectric switching with low voltage is advantageous for application in many microelectronic devices including nonvolatile memory, rollable display, and electronic papers. The hysteretic PFM loops as a function of
V
read
are also observed in
Figure S12
, revealing ferroelectric behaviors such as butterfly amplitude loops and above 180° phase flips in the drop-casted samples. However, such hysteretic behaviors are not observed in both spin-coated and spin/vacuum-treated films (see
Figures S13 and S14
). The cKPFM responses in the on-fields (
Figures S13a and S14a
) follow the applied bias signals, while the responses are nonlinear with no hysteretic behavior (
Figures S13b and S14b
). In addition, no butterfly amplitude loops are observed on both films with only phase flips at 0 V in the PFM loops (
Figures S13c, S13d, S14c, and S14d
). This indicates that the signals are dominantly from the electrostatic contribution with the absence of ferroelectric dynamics. Our cKPFM results suggest that the ferroelectricity is dependent on the strain in the 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin films.

To investigate the effect of film thickness on the ferroelectricity, we fabricated thin films of 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
perovskite with spin speeds of 4000 and 6000 rpms. As compared to the previous thin films fabricated with 2000 rpm (resulting in a thickness of around 300 nm), the films fabricated with 4000 rpm (
Figure S15a
) are relatively uniform and dense with a lower thickness of around 100 nm. However, ferroelectricity is not observed in the cKPFM responses of this film (
Figure S15b
). With a higher spin speed of 6000 rpm, the film is fabricated but is not properly deposited on the substrate as shown in
Figure S16a
. Note that a higher spin speed, ≥6000 rpm, significantly disperses the precursor solution during the spin-coating process. Similarly, ferroelectricity is not observed in the cKPFM responses of such film (
Figure S16b
). Although the film thickness can be modulated from several hundreds of nanometers to a few nanometers (assisted by vacuum treatment) via the spin-coating method, ferroelectricity does not appear in these films. Therefore, microscale film thickness fabricated by the drop-casting method is essential for ferroelectricity in 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
perovskite.

As discussed previosly, strain can be also tuned by grain sizes. Microscopically, we observe different grain sizes in the strain-engineered films (
Figure
1
). The higher strain with reduced grain size removes ferroelectricity in the spin-coated samples because strain induces structural modification. Previously, the effect of grain size on strain was observed in 3D polycrystalline MAPbI
3
thin films.
(70)
In particular, the significantly reduced grain size to the nanoscale in the spin/vacuum-treated film results in the increased grain boundaries which act as channels for charge transport. Thus, the increased strain from decreased grain size and increased grain-boundary density can limit ferroelectricity.

To further explore the optical properties of 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
perovskite samples, photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was performed with 1-photon (1p) and 2-photon (2p) excitation as shown in
Figure
3
. PL spectroscopy with excitation above the band gap (1p) identifies the properties of the surface layer of a few hundred nanometers, which relies on the light penetration depth. On the contrary, the PL spectra with 2p excitation are generated from the bulk properties because of the long light penetration depth.
(71)
Thus, the PL spectra between 1p and 2p excitations in HOIPs can show a substantial difference in the PL peak positions. Further, the second-harmonic generation (SHG) with 2p excitation is a complementary technique that is dependent on the inversion symmetry of the materials. SHG is significantly sensitive to local symmetry breaking that is required in ferroelectric materials. It is known that SHG is the conversion of a specific wavelength of light, for example, half wavelength from the original laser, λ
1
→ 1/2 λ
1
, or frequency doubling, ω
1
→ 2 ω
1
.
(72)
The large optical fields induce the polarization, P, in the materials, where P is determined by the linear electric susceptibility. This phenomenon leads to nonlinear effects such as SHG. Typically, using a commercially available Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm, incident beam), SHG can appear at a wavelength of around 532 nm. Here, the SHG measurement was performed using a 1030 nm wavelength laser. Consequently, the SHG appears at 513 nm, which is almost one-half the wavelength of the incident laser. Furthermore, the SHG peak is detected when the domain polarization of the materials interacts with the incident laser polarization.
(73)
However, the low-intensity SHG peak can result from scattering by multiple domain structures with inverted polarity, leading to destructive interference between SHG responses.
(24)
It was also reported that the SHG peak intensity can be dependent on the particle size in hybrid perovskites.
(74)

div.p:
Figure 3. PL spectroscopy on (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
crystal and thin films. (a) PL spectra after 1-photon excitation, (b) enlarged green box in a, c) PL spectra after 2-photon excitation, and (d) enlarged SHG peaks on the (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
crystal, drop-casted, spin-coated, and vacuum-treated samples.

div.div:
For the crystal (
Figure
3
a and
3
b), there are two emission peaks at 528 and 590 nm with 1p excitation. The two emission peaks on the drop-casted film are observed at 528 nm as a shoulder and at 563 nm that is a blue shift from 590 nm on the crystal. Three peaks are apparent in 1p excitation (528, 563, and 590 nm), but the emissive character is different between bulk (crystal and drop-casted) samples and (spin-coated and vacuum-treated) thin film samples. The bulk samples with low strain show a narrow emission at 528 nm and a major peak at 563 and 590 nm, while thin film samples with high strain only show a narrow emission at 528 nm. The 528, 563, and 590 nm peaks are attributed to surface and bulk emission, respectively.
(75)
The observed double peaks with 1p excitation are associated with a self-absorption effect.
(76)
The first peak is directly emitted from the surface, while the second peak stems from multiple internal reflections and self-absorption.
(76)
Thus, we attribute the appearance of these double peaks in both crystal and drop-casted films to multiple internal reflections. Meanwhile, only one peak appears on both spin-coated and vacuum-treated films (
Figure
3
a and
3
b). Interestingly, the intensities of the emission peaks are significantly higher for the drop-casted film, as shown in
Figure
3
a and
3
b. We consider this increased intensity and peak shift to the strain-induced band-gap shift. The strain-induced band-gap modulation is widely explained in classical semiconductors.
(77)
As discussed, lattice strain leads to significant alternation of the bond strength and thus modulates the energy band structures. Looking at
Figure
3
c and
3
d, the detected SHG peak at 513 nm is the strongest for the crystal, followed by the drop-casted film. It is expected that the crystal contains the lowest concentration of defects as compared to the thin film sample. A defect site alone is unable to generate a SHG peak since the SHG signal is induced by inversion symmetry of the lattice. The 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
studied here belongs to a noncentrosymmetric group,
Aba
2, at room temperature,
(31)
and hence, the observed SHG peak in our results originates from inversion symmetry in the bulk of the material. In addition, for the major emission peaks, those with the strongest emission from the crystal and drop-casted film, we observe a slight blue shift to 585 nm in the drop-casted film from the 595 nm emission from the crystal. This wavelength shift can be also associated with strain-induced band-gap modulation in the thin film. It is interesting to note that a significant decrease in the peak intensity is observed on the films. One possible reason for this phenomenon could be due to a higher surface-to-volume ratio by crystallization during film deposition. For the thinner film (spin coated) with higher strains, the SHG peak appears at 513 nm with significantly decreased intensity as shown in
Figure
3
c. Note that the SHG peak still exists on the spin/vacuum-treated film with a much weaker intensity as shown in
Figure S17
. Clearly, as the strain increases, the SHG peaks are greatly reduced. Yet, the PL remains bright. It is well understood that the presence of defects can typically degrade the PL, but all samples in this study still show high PL intensity. Thus, a large concentration of defects is not anticipated. The SHG peak is generated when an incident laser interacts with the internal domain polarization in a material. However, multiple internal polarizations from the domains in the crystal scatter the signals, leading to a considerably lower intensity of the SHG peak.
(24)
The SHG peak intensity in our results is strongly dependent on the strain disorder, which can be changed by the film thickness. Clearly, the film thickness is associated with the strain disorder and structural evolution. It was also previously reported for materials such as BiFeO
3
and layered GaSe that the film thickness influences the SHG peak intensity.
(78−80)

The morphological factors, i.e., grain size and grain boundary, increase the intrinsic strain in the spin/vacuum-treated film by 386% (obtained from differences in the strain disorder in
Table S1
) as compared to the drop-casted film. These reduce the ferroelectricity in the spin-coated thin films as probed by SHG and cKPFM measurements. In our experiments, the SHG intensity is sensitive to the absence of inversion symmetry and the polar and ferroelectric nature of the samples. Among the four samples, as the strain increases from a crystal to a vacuum-treated film, the SHG signal decreases. This indicates that at high strain the polar nature and thus ferroelectricity in the material is diminished. The ferroelectric polarization in (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
is observed in the thicker sample with low strain, while the spin-coated and vacuum-treated samples possess high strain and surface states that diminish ferroelectricity. These results show a strong correlation between the surface PL dynamics and the ferroelectricity in 2D HOIPs with different strains. The variation in the SHG signifies a correlation among the ferroelectricity, grain size, and strain which may be used to control the nonlinear optical properties in this class of materials.

This result is in agreement with the cKPFM results in the previous section, demonstrating ferroelectricity in the low-strain thin film of 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
. Evidently for the 2D HOIPs, strain engineering is an outstanding strategy to tune the electromechanical and optical properties.

To gain further insight into the surface charge properties and photovoltage, KPFM measurements were carried out in the dark and under illumination on the strain-engineered 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin films coated on SnO
2
/ITO substrate. Note that all measurements were performed under ambient conditions. The light source shined from the bottom through the glass substrate to illuminate the perovskite films. The surface potential (contact potential difference, CPD) in KPFM is determined by the electrochemical potential of either the electrons or the holes between the KPFM tip and the sample. Also, the surface photovoltage, CPD
light
– CPD
dark
, provides information on the charge generation, recombination, and local charge properties.

We performed KPFM measurements over an area of 2 μm
2
on the films to avoid the topological cross-talk and roughness effect.
Figure
4
a shows the CPD distributions in the dark and under illumination in the three different films. The corresponding topography and CPD maps in the dark are shown in
Figure S18
. The highest CPD value, ∼413 mV, is measured on the drop-casted film in the pristine surface potential, corresponding to a film with ferroelectricity. The enhanced surface potential of the drop-casted film is associated with the ferroelectric polarization charge compared to other films. Under illumination, the surface potentials are increased in all films. The illumination provokes photogenerated charge carriers, which is effectively separated by the built-in potential at the interface between 2D perovskite and SnO
2
. Since the electron transport layer (SnO
2
) was deposited underneath the perovskite layer, we expect that the photogenerated holes move to the top surface of the film by the AFM tip while the photogenerated electrons move to the bottom transport layer.
(81)
To directly compare the surface photovoltages, the CPD variations with time after normalizing the CPD values are plotted in
Figure
4
b. The corresponding CPD maps are displayed in
Figure S19
. Average CPD changes are ∼120 mV for the drop-casted film, ∼150 mV for the spin-coated film, and ∼210 mV for the vacuum-treated film. As can be seen, the vacuum-treated film shows the highest surface photovoltage. The surface photovoltage is directly associated with decreased grain size and increased density of grain boundaries, affecting the charge transport.
(81)
Besides, the thinner films absorb more light and produce more photogenerated carriers.

div.p:
Figure 4. KPFM and local
I–V
measurements on (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin films. (a) CPD distribution of different thin films in the dark and under illumination. (b) Time-dependent CPD variations in the dark and under illumination. (c) Local photocurrent measurements on different thin films.

div.div:
In the classical approximation, the ferroelectric properties are sensitive to the strain via simple Ginzburg–Landau theory.
(82)
This model predicts the relationship among the domain structures, ferroelectric properties, and parameters affecting strain, e.g., film thickness, defect distributions, etc. However, the ferroelectricity is not sensitive to the charge carrier concentration, which can affect the polarization switching but not the polarization itself.

Typically, charge carriers are trapped at the defects, which leads to either the charge carrier accumulation or dissipation. This can lead to hysteresis or other hysteretic phenomena, which resembles the ferroelectric properties. Owing to the relationship between the defect density and the charge accumulation, we explored the surface defects using KPFM measurements (
Figure S20
). The low contact potential difference (CPD, dark region) observed in the KPFM maps can be associated with potential defect sites. Recently, S. D. Stranks. et al. systematically studied these defects, revealing nanoscale clustered traps with excess iodide.
(47)
To investigate whether the dark regions are topological cross-talk, we also analyzed the line profiles on each map in
Figure S20c, S20f, and S20i
. As a result, there was no direct correlation between the CPD profile and the height. Hence, the dark regions can be associated with the trap sites. A majority of the traps with the lowest CPD are observed in the spin-coated film than the other films. However, ferroelectricity is not observed in the spin-coated films. Thus, we rule out trapping charge carriers as a reason for the ferroelectricity.

We further explored the local charge transport properties using conductive atomic force microscopy (c-AFM) to measure the local
I–V
characteristics of the films under illumination as shown in
Figure
4
c. A small current of ∼0.1 nA is detected in the drop-casted film, accompanying small hysteresis.
Figure S21
shows the
I–V
characteristics on different locations in the drop-casted film. We further performed local
I–V
measurements in the drop-casted films to investigate the current response. Despite a lower current of a few pA, negative currents of around 20 pA can be seen in all results. Further, it was previously reported that at higher biases (>10 kV/cm) a distinct
I–V
hysteresis can be observed in this material correlating with its ferroelectricity.
(31)
Thus, such
I–V
hysteresis in the drop-casted film can be associated with ferroelectricity with nonzero current at zero bias. Also, these
I–V
hysteretic behaviors can be related to the electroresistance dynamic.
(45)
We should also note that the small current could be due to the nonideality of the current amplifier. On the other hand, a much higher current of ±50 nA is measured in the thinner films fabricated by vacuum treatment. This result is in agreement with the photovoltage measured by KPFM. A higher surface photovoltage and current are observed in the vacuum-treated films with nanoscale grains and a high density of grain boundaries. We further explored the diode characteristics of each sample in a planar electrode design under illumination. The results are shown in
Figure S22
. As expected, a strong
I–V
hysteresis with low current is observed in the drop-casted film (
Figure S22a
), while a relatively small hysteresis with higher current is measured in the spin-coated and vacuum-treated films (
Figure S22b and S22c
). This trend provides a clear difference among the strain-engineered films. Nonetheless, these results cannot provide a direct correlation between ferroelectricity and charge carrier transport as the origin of ferroelectricity in this material is not fully understood. Consequently, strain engineering in 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
thin films by controlling the crystallinity, grain size, and film thickness can be versatile not only in tuning ferroelectricity but also in controlling charge transport.

The ferroelectricity leads to a polarization-induced internal electric field. This aids in efficiently separating the photogenerated charge carriers, resulting in effective built-in fields at the interface between the ferroelectric and the electrode due to formation of Schottky barriers.
(16)
Further, the ferroelectricity provides unique photovoltaic behaviors such as a switchable photovoltaic phenomenon,
(83)
above-band-gap photovoltages,
(17)
and light-dependent polarization.
(19)
Despite the presence of ferroelectricity in the drop-casted film, the surface photovoltage and photocurrent are relatively smaller than those of the other two films with no ferroelectricity. This can be the result of poor light absorption due to the film thickness. In addition, the strain gradient in the drop-casted film could be detrimental to the charge transport. We should note that the large energy mismatch between the band gaps of the ferroelectrics and the solar spectrum can induce poor light absorption accompanying low photocurrent. To overcome this issue, tremendous efforts have been made to tune the band gap by chemical substitution,
(84−86)
leading to a higher power conversion efficiency in ferroelectric photovoltaics.

Our results clarify that strain engineering in 2D HOIPs can modulate the electromechanical, optical, and electrical properties. Considering these factors, strain engineering in 2D HOIPs is a powerful strategy for achieving targeted performance such as lowering the ferroelectric switching voltages, tuning the optical band gap, the photovoltage, and the photocurrent.

div.div:
We have successfully grown (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
crystals by a slow-cooling crystallization method. The thin films of 2D (4,4-DFPD)
2
PbI
4
were fabricated with different deposition techniques by dissolving the crystals in DMSO solvent as a precursor solution. The XRD patterns confirm different crystallinity and strain disorder in the films depending on the fabrication conditions. AFM imaging reveals that topological features are dependent on the strain. The PFM and BE-PFM/cKPFM results provide insight into the ferroelectric response of the drop-casted film with a low switching voltage. However, no ferroelectric response was observed from both the spin-coated and the vacuum-treated samples. PL spectroscopy with 1p excitation revealed that the optical properties such as the band gap can be tuned via strain. It is interesting to observe the significant decrease in the PL intensity as strain increases. This could be possibly due to the strain-induced transition of the optical band gap. A strong SHG peak with 2p excitation was observed in the drop-casted and as-grown crystals, while this peak is significantly weaker in both spin-coated and vacuum-treated samples. This result further supports the noncentrosymmetric nature of the structure in the ferroelectric drop-casted film with low strain disorder. Further, the KPFM results show that a higher surface potential occurs in the drop-casted sample than in the other two samples, while the photovoltage in the vacuum-treated sample is the highest. Likewise, the highest photocurrent measured from the local
I–V
characteristics is observed in the vacuum-treated sample. Although ferroelectricity is not observed on the vacuum-treated sample, uniformly dispersed films help to obtain a higher photovoltage and current. It is expected that strain engineering in 2D HOIPs will provide a new pathway to develop devices with tuned electromechanical and optoelectronic properties.

Next-generation displays and lighting technologies require efficient optical sources that combine brightness, color purity, stability, substrate flexibility. Metal halide perovskites have potential use in a wide range of applications, for they possess excellent charge transport, bandgap tunability and, in the most promising recent optical source materials, intense and efficient luminescence. This review links metal halide perovskites' performance as efficient light emitters with their underlying materials electronic and photophys. attributes.

A review. Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites have been intensively researched in the past decade for their optoelectronic properties. The emergence of Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, which have mixed dimensionality, has heralded new opportunities for tailor-made semiconductors that combine enhanced stability with useful properties between those of 2D and 3D systems. Inspired by advances in 2D materials research, there is growing interest in molecularly thin versions of these hybrid perovskites, owing to their ease of incorporation into electronic devices. There is, thus, a need to understand thickness-dependent elec., excitonic and phononic properties that go beyond quantum-confinement effects. Recent studies have shown that, apart from tuning the dimensionality of the system, fine-tuning its thickness also helps to optimize performance in different applications, ranging from third-harmonic generation to photodetectors and spintronics.

Org.-inorg. perovskites showed promise as high-performance absorbers in solar cells, 1st as a coating on a mesoporous metal oxide scaffold and more recently as a solid layer in planar heterojunction architectures. Here, the authors report transient absorption and photoluminescence-quenching measurements to det. the electron-hole diffusion lengths, diffusion consts., and lifetimes in mixed halide (MeNH3PbI3-xClx) and triiodide (MeNH3PbI3) perovskite absorbers. The diffusion lengths are >1 μm in the mixed halide perovskite, which is an order of magnitude greater than the absorption depth. But the triiodide absorber has electron-hole diffusion lengths of about 100 nm. These results justify the high efficiency of planar heterojunction perovskite solar cells and identify a crit. parameter to optimize for future perovskite absorber development.

We elucidate the mechanism of a newly obsd. photovoltaic effect which occurs in ferroelecs. with periodic domain structures. Under sufficiently strong illumination, domain walls function as nanoscale generators of the photovoltaic current. The steps in the electrostatic potential function to accumulate electrons and holes on opposite sides of the walls while locally reducing the concn. of the oppositely charged carriers. As a result, the recombination rate adjacent to the walls is reduced, leading to a net diffusion current. Solvation plays a pivotal role in chem. and biol. A solid-state analogy of solvation is polaron formation, but the magnitude of Coulomb screening is typically an order of magnitude weaker than that of solvation in aq. solns. Here, we describe a new class of polarons, the ferroelec. large polaron, proposed initially by Miyata and Zhu in 2018 (). This type of polaron allows efficient Coulomb screening of an electron or hole by extended ordering of dipoles from symmetry-broken unit cells. The local ordering is reflected in the ferroelec.-like THz dielec. responses of lead halide perovskites (LHPs) and may be partially responsible for their exceptional optoelectronic performances. Despite the likely absence of long-range ferroelectricity in LHPs, a charge carrier may be localized to and/or induce the formation of nanoscale domain boundaries of locally ordered dipoles. Based on the known planar nature of energetically favorable domain boundaries in ferroelec. materials, we propose that a ferroelec. polaron localizes to planar boundaries of transient polar nanodomains. This proposal is supported by dynamic simulations showing sheet-like transient electron or hole wave functions in LHPs. Thus, the Belgian-waffle-shaped ferroelec. polaron in the three-dimensional LHP crystal structure is a large polaron in two dimensions and a small polaron in the perpendicular direction. The ferroelec. large polaron may form in other cryst. solids characterized by dynamic symmetry breaking and polar fluctuations. We suggest that the ability to form ferroelec. large polarons can be a general principle for the efficient screening of charge carriers from scattering with other charge carriers, with charged defects and with longitudinal optical phonons, thus contributing to enhanced optoelectronic properties.

A review. Semiconductor nanocrystals are tiny light-emitting particles on the nanometer scale. Researchers have studied these particles intensely and have developed them for broad applications in solar energy conversion, optoelectronic devices, mol. and cellular imaging, and ultrasensitive detection. A major feature of semiconductor nanocrystals is the quantum confinement effect, which leads to spatial enclosure of the electronic charge carriers within the nanocrystal. Because of this effect, researchers can use the size and shape of these artificial atoms to widely and precisely tune the energy of discrete electronic energy states and optical transitions. As a result, researchers can tune the light emission from these particles throughout the UV, visible, near-IR, and mid-IR spectral ranges. These particles also span the transition between small mols. and bulk crystals, instilling novel optical properties such as carrier multiplication, single-particle blinking, and spectral diffusion. Semiconductor nanocrystals provide a versatile building block for developing complex nanostructures such as superlattices and multimodal agents for mol. imaging and targeted therapy. In this Account, recent advances in the understanding of the at. structure and optical properties of semiconductor nanocrystals are discussed. The authors also discuss new strategies for band gap and electronic wave function engineering to control the location of charge carriers. New methodologies such as alloying, doping, strain-tuning, and band-edge warping will likely play key roles in the further development of these particles for optoelectronic and biomedical applications.

The surface and interface sensitive nonlinear optical technique of second-harmonic generation (SHG) is a very useful diagnostic in studying surface and interface properties in thin film systems and can provide relevant information during thin film processing. An important aspect when applying SHG is the interpretation of the SHG response. In order to utilize the full potential of SHG during materials processing it is necessary to have a good understanding of both the macroscopic and the microscopic origin of the SHG response, particularly in thin film or multilayer systems where the propagation of radiation is another important aspect that should be considered carefully. A brief theor. overview on the origin of the SHG response and a description of the propagation of radiation will be given. Furthermore, several methods will be discussed that might reveal the possible macroscopic and microscopic origins of the SHG response in thin film systems. The different approaches will be illustrated by examples of real-time and spectroscopic SHG expts. with thin film systems relevant in Si etching and deposition environments, such as (1) hydrogenated amorphous Si films deposited by hot-wire chem. vapor deposition on both Si(100) and fused silica substrates, (2) amorphous Si generated by low-energy Ar+-ion bombardment of H terminated Si(100), and (3) Al2O3 films deposited by plasma-assisted at. layer deposition on H terminated Si(100). Unidirectional elec. current flow, such as that found in a diode, is essential for modern electronics. It usually occurs at asym. interfaces such as p-n junctions or metal/semiconductor interfaces with Schottky barriers. We report on a diode effect assocd. with the direction of bulk elec. polarization in BiFeO3: a ferroelec. with a small optical gap edge of ~2.2 eV. Bulk elec. conduction in ferroelec. monodomain BiFeO3 crystals is highly nonlinear and unidirectional. This diode effect switches its direction when the elec. polarization is flipped by an external voltage. A substantial visible-light photovoltaic effect is obsd. in BiFeO3 diode structures. The electronic band gap is a fundamental material parameter requiring control for light harvesting, conversion and transport technologies, including photovoltaics, lasers and sensors. Although traditional methods to tune band gaps rely on chem. alloying, quantum size effects, lattice mismatch or superlattice formation, the spectral variation is often limited to <1 eV, unless marked changes to compn. or structure occur. Here we report large band gap changes of up to 200% or ∼2 eV without modifying chem. compn. or use of epitaxial strain in the LaSrAlO4 Ruddlesden-Popper oxide. First-principles calcns. show that ordering elec. charged [LaO]1+ and neutral [SrO]0 monoxide planes imposes internal elec. fields in the layered oxides. These fields drive local at. displacements and bond distortions that control the energy levels at the valence and conduction band edges, providing a path towards electronic structure engineering in complex oxides.

Photoferroelectrics offer unique opportunities to explore light energy conversion based on their polarization-driven carrier separation and above-bandgap voltages. The problem associated with the wide bandgap of ferroelectric oxides, i.e., the vanishingly small photoresponse under visible light, has been overcome partly by bandgap tuning, but the narrowing of the bandgap is, in principle, accompanied by a substantial loss of ferroelectric polarization. In this article, we report an approach, 'gap-state' engineering, to produce photoferroelectrics, in which defect states within the bandgap act as a scaffold for photogeneration. Our first-principles calculations and single-domain thin-film experiments of BiFeO3 demonstrate that gap states half-filled with electrons can enhance not only photocurrents but also photovoltages over a broad photon-energy range that is different from intermediate bands in present semiconductor-based solar cells. Our approach opens a promising route to the material design of visible-light-active ferroelectrics without sacrificing spontaneous polarization.Overcoming the optical transparency of wide bandgap of ferroelectric oxides by narrowing its bandgap tends to result in a loss of polarization. By utilizing defect states within the bandgap, Matsuo et al. report visible-light-active ferroelectrics without sacrificing polarization.

A review. Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites have been intensively researched in the past decade for their optoelectronic properties. The emergence of Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites, which have mixed dimensionality, has heralded new opportunities for tailor-made semiconductors that combine enhanced stability with useful properties between those of 2D and 3D systems. There is, thus, a need to understand thickness-dependent elec., excitonic and phononic properties that go beyond quantum-confinement effects. Three-dimensional org.-inorg. perovskites have emerged as one of the most promising thin-film solar cell materials owing to their remarkable photophys. properties, which have led to power conversion efficiencies exceeding 20 per cent, with the prospect of further improvements towards the Shockley-Queisser limit for a single-junction solar cell (33.5 per cent). Besides efficiency, another crit. factor for photovoltaics and other optoelectronic applications is environmental stability and photostability under operating conditions. In contrast to their three-dimensional counterparts, Ruddlesden-Popper phases-layered two-dimensional perovskite films-have shown promising stability, but poor efficiency at only 4.73 per cent. This relatively poor efficiency is attributed to the inhibition of out-of-plane charge transport by the org. cations, which act like insulating spacing layers between the conducting inorg. slabs. Here we overcome this issue in layered perovskites by producing thin films of near-single-cryst. quality, in which the crystallog. planes of the inorg. perovskite component have a strongly preferential out-of-plane alignment with respect to the contacts in planar solar cells to facilitate efficient charge transport. We report a photovoltaic efficiency of 12.52 per cent with no hysteresis, and the devices exhibit greatly improved stability in comparison to their three-dimensional counterparts when subjected to light, humidity and heat stress tests. Unencapsulated two-dimensional perovskite devices retain over 60 per cent of their efficiency for over 2,250 h under const., std. (AM1.5G) illumination, and exhibit greater tolerance to 65 per cent relative humidity than do three-dimensional equiv. When the devices are encapsulated, the layered devices do not show any degrdn. under const. AM1.5G illumination or humidity. Organometal halide perovskites exhibit large bulk crystal domain sizes, rare traps, excellent mobilities and carriers that are free at room temp.-properties that support their excellent performance in charge-sepg. devices. In devices that rely on the forward injection of electrons and holes, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), excellent mobilities contribute to the efficient capture of non-equil. charge carriers by rare non-radiative centers. Moreover, the lack of bound excitons weakens the competition of desired radiative (over undesired non-radiative) recombination. Here we report a perovskite mixed material comprising a series of differently quantum-size-tuned grains that funnels photoexcitations to the lowest-bandgap light-emitter in the mixt. The materials function as charge carrier concentrators, ensuring that radiative recombination successfully out-competes trapping and hence non-radiative recombination. We use the new material to build devices that exhibit an external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 8.8% and a radiance of 80 W sr-1 m-2. These represent the brightest and most efficient soln.-processed near-IR LEDs to date.

Using d. functional theory (DFT), we show that a low energy of formation, exacerbated in the presence of humidity, explains the propensity of perovskites to decomp. back into their precursors. Solvation plays a pivotal role in chem. and biol. A solid-state analogy of solvation is polaron formation, but the magnitude of Coulomb screening is typically an order of magnitude weaker than that of solvation in aq. solns. Here, we describe a new class of polarons, the ferroelec. large polaron, proposed initially by Miyata and Zhu in 2018 (). This type of polaron allows efficient Coulomb screening of an electron or hole by extended ordering of dipoles from symmetry-broken unit cells. The local ordering is reflected in the ferroelec.-like THz dielec. responses of lead halide perovskites (LHPs) and may be partially responsible for their exceptional optoelectronic performances. Despite the likely absence of long-range ferroelectricity in LHPs, a charge carrier may be localized to and/or induce the formation of nanoscale domain boundaries of locally ordered dipoles. Based on the known planar nature of energetically favorable domain boundaries in ferroelec. materials, we propose that a ferroelec. polaron localizes to planar boundaries of transient polar nanodomains. This proposal is supported by dynamic simulations showing sheet-like transient electron or hole wave functions in LHPs. Thus, the Belgian-waffle-shaped ferroelec. polaron in the three-dimensional LHP crystal structure is a large polaron in two dimensions and a small polaron in the perpendicular direction. The ferroelec. large polaron may form in other cryst. solids characterized by dynamic symmetry breaking and polar fluctuations. We suggest that the ability to form ferroelec. large polarons can be a general principle for the efficient screening of charge carriers from scattering with other charge carriers, with charged defects and with longitudinal optical phonons, thus contributing to enhanced optoelectronic properties.

A review. Semiconductor nanocrystals are tiny light-emitting particles on the nanometer scale. Researchers have studied these particles intensely and have developed them for broad applications in solar energy conversion, optoelectronic devices, mol. and cellular imaging, and ultrasensitive detection. A major feature of semiconductor nanocrystals is the quantum confinement effect, which leads to spatial enclosure of the electronic charge carriers within the nanocrystal. Because of this effect, researchers can use the size and shape of these artificial atoms to widely and precisely tune the energy of discrete electronic energy states and optical transitions. As a result, researchers can tune the light emission from these particles throughout the UV, visible, near-IR, and mid-IR spectral ranges. These particles also span the transition between small mols. and bulk crystals, instilling novel optical properties such as carrier multiplication, single-particle blinking, and spectral diffusion. Semiconductor nanocrystals provide a versatile building block for developing complex nanostructures such as superlattices and multimodal agents for mol. imaging and targeted therapy. In this Account, recent advances in the understanding of the at. structure and optical properties of semiconductor nanocrystals are discussed. The authors also discuss new strategies for band gap and electronic wave function engineering to control the location of charge carriers. New methodologies such as alloying, doping, strain-tuning, and band-edge warping will likely play key roles in the further development of these particles for optoelectronic and biomedical applications.

Multiferroic films are increasingly being studied for applications in solar energy conversion because of their efficient ferroelec. polarization-driven carrier sepn. and above-bandgap generated photovoltages, which in principle can lead to energy conversion efficiencies beyond the max. value (∼34%) reported in traditional silicon-based bipolar heterojunction solar cells. However, the efficiency reported so far is still too low (<2%) to be considered for commercialization. Here, we demonstrate a new approach to effectively tune the bandgap of double perovskite multiferroic oxides by engineering the cationic ordering for the case of Bi2FeCrO6. Using this approach, we report a power conversion efficiency of 8.1% under AM 1.5 G irradn. (100 mW cm-2) for Bi2FeCrO6 thin-film solar cells in a multilayer configuration.

Matsuo Hiroki; Matsuo Hiroki; Noguchi Yuji; Miyayama Masaru

Photoferroelectrics offer unique opportunities to explore light energy conversion based on their polarization-driven carrier separation and above-bandgap voltages. The problem associated with the wide bandgap of ferroelectric oxides, i.e., the vanishingly small photoresponse under visible light, has been overcome partly by bandgap tuning, but the narrowing of the bandgap is, in principle, accompanied by a substantial loss of ferroelectric polarization. In this article, we report an approach, 'gap-state' engineering, to produce photoferroelectrics, in which defect states within the bandgap act as a scaffold for photogeneration. Our first-principles calculations and single-domain thin-film experiments of BiFeO3 demonstrate that gap states half-filled with electrons can enhance not only photocurrents but also photovoltages over a broad photon-energy range that is different from intermediate bands in present semiconductor-based solar cells. Our approach opens a promising route to the material design of visible-light-active ferroelectrics without sacrificing spontaneous polarization.Overcoming the optical transparency of wide bandgap of ferroelectric oxides by narrowing its bandgap tends to result in a loss of polarization. By utilizing defect states within the bandgap, Matsuo et al. report visible-light-active ferroelectrics without sacrificing polarization.
